unittitle.value: Alice Wexler Research Files on Emma Goldman

abstract.value: Alice Wexler (1942-) is the author of two biographies on Emma Goldman: <emph render="italic">Emma Goldman in America</emph> (1984), which tracks Goldman's political career in the United States up to her deportation, and <emph render="italic">Emma Goldman in Exile</emph> (1989), which cover's Goldman's life from 1919 until her death in 1940. The collection is mostly comprised of copies of primary materials related to Emma Goldman (correspondence, news articles, etc.), collected and often annotated by Wexler in the course of conducting her research.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Alice Wexler Research Files on Emma Goldman; TAM 620; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Alice Wexler in 2012; additional materials were donated in 2014. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2012.052, 2014.171, 2014.083.

Alice Wexler (1942-) received a Ph.D. in history from Indiana University in 1972. She has taught at UC Riverside, the California Institute of Technology, Claremont Graduate School, Occidental College and UCLA. Wexler is the author of two biographies on Emma Goldman: <emph render="italic">Emma Goldman in America</emph> (1984), which tracks Goldman's political career in the United States up to her deportation, and <emph render="italic">Emma Goldman in Exile</emph> (1989), which cover's Goldman's life from 1919 until her death in 1940. Wexler's other books include <emph render="italic">Mapping Fate: A Memoir of Family, Risk, and Genetic Research</emph> (1996) and <emph render="italic">The Woman Who Walked Into the Sea: Huntington's the Making of a Genetic Disease</emph> (2008). She has been a Research Scholar at UCLA's Center for the Study of Women since 1994.

A set of correspondendence donated in 2014 includes letters to Wexler (dated 1974-1985) relating to her research on Emma Goldman and the publication of her work. Correspondents include Ahrne Thorne, Richard Drinnon, Federico Arcos, Kay Boyle, Paul Avrich, and Daniel Malmed.
